glmcs 0.1.0
  • Reference

Fit a Univariate Effect via IRLS for GLM or Cox Models

Source: R/core.R
univarite_fit.Rd

Estimates a single regression coefficient θ for one predictor by solving the iteratively reweighted least squares (IRLS) equations. Works for both generalized linear models (via univariate_irls_glm) and Cox proportional hazards (via univariate_irls_cox).

univarite_fit(
  x,
  y,
  family,
  offset = 0,
  standardize = TRUE,
  ties = "efron",
  null_threshold = 1e-06
)

Arguments

x

Numeric vector of length n. The single predictor.

y

Response:

  • Numeric vector (length n) for GLMs.

  • Numeric matrix (n × 2) with columns (time, status) for Cox.

family

A GLM family object (e.g. gaussian(), binomial(), poisson(), …) or a list with family = "cox" for Cox regression.

offset

Numeric scalar or vector of length n. Known offset in the linear predictor (default: 0).

standardize

Logical. If TRUE, center and scale x before fitting (default: TRUE), so that θ is on the original scale.

ties

Character. Tie-handling method for Cox IRLS: "efron" (default) or "breslow". Ignored for GLMs.

null_threshold

Numeric. Estimates with absolute value ≤ this threshold are set to zero (default: 1e-6).

Value

A list with components:

theta

Estimated regression coefficient θ (on original scale).

loglik

Log-likelihood evaluated at θ.

bic

Bayesian Information Criterion, \(-2*loglik + 2\,\log(n)\).

See also

glm, glmnet, univariate_irls_glm, univariate_loglik

Examples

## Gaussian example
set.seed(1)
x <- rnorm(100)
y <- 1 + 2 * x + rnorm(100)
univarite_fit(x, y, family = gaussian())
#> Warning: Non-positive or non-finite denom in IRLS; returning current slope.
#> $theta
#> [1] 0
#> 
#> $loglik
#> [1] -274.6034
#> 
#> $bic
#> [1] 558.4172
#> 

## Logistic regression
set.seed(2)
x <- rnorm(200)
eta <- -0.5 + 1.5 * x
p <- 1 / (1 + exp(-eta))
y <- rbinom(200, 1, p)
univarite_fit(x, y, family = binomial())
#> $theta
#> [1] 1.506598
#> 
#> $loglik
#> [1] -99.78803
#> 
#> $bic
#> [1] 210.1727
#>
